Just want to say that it was not because of integrated circuits that America beat Rusha to the moon, it was luck. Rusha was actually the one ready to launch first, trying to send their rover Lunokhod to the moon, but due to a rocket failure, it exploded. The US then launched soon after and had a successful mission. Lunokhod was rebuilt and Rusha launched again (this time without the exploding.) and they too then had a successful mission.  Loving the series, by the way, Just wanted to clear things up regarding how the space race was won. Rusha really was not that far off the mark when it came to space technology then people think.

Its a little sycophantic to give so much credit to our government. You do say, even in your own presentation that Japanese consumer level products came in and dominated despite (though perhaps because of) our government spending so much. You can't simply assert that the NSF is beneficial just because they spend money because you have to take into account what else that money may have been spent on and whether it spends money on successful projects or failed projects since failed projects further distort the marketplace by wasting time and resources that would otherwise have been put to better uses. Think about what all those highly intelligent people working for the NSA to spy on us for no benefit might have done in the private sector where they actually have to produce something useful to society to profit.  That government spending was a misallocation of resources which ended up having a very limited benefit (which is the general trend of how government allocates money in every area) leaving our market open to competition from the Japanese. You always see the private sector overcoming this government interference in the market, not benefiting from it. This goes way back to steam ships railroads and airplanes and continues to this day with rocketry and drones and even disaster relief.

The US could have launched the first satellite months before the USSR but President Eisenhower didn't want to use a rocket designed for delivering bombs. After a series of failures by the Navy he gave Werner Von Braun and his JPL team the OK. They had already built a satellite against orders, hoping they would be called on. Their satellite, Explorer I, was sussessful on the first try and discovered the Van Allen radiation belts that surround the Earth. JPL later became a vital part of NASA.

We continuously fall prey to the misconceptions that government was the one that pioneered technologies. Government merely hired the talent from the private sector and threw endless tax payer's dollars at them until they came up with a solution to their militaristic goals. The private sector would have accomplished these same sorts of technologies, like the IC, as the market acknowledged the usefulness of the application, and the manufacturing costs could be controlled in a reasonable fashion - unlike government who threw money into the wind. The concept of networked computing and integrated circuits, for example, existed well before the government funded them as the first to the scene investors. I cringe when people say that, "Without government, we wouldn't have all the technology we have today!" Poppycock.
How do you manage to make an episode about Computer Science during the cold war and spend only about a minute of the USSR and it's computer-related programmes?

That happens to every technology as physical limitations are reached. Automobile technology hasn't majorly changed in decades, just slight refinements. Once cable internet/TV is reaching it's speed limit now that much of it has been replaced with fiber optics. Except for sports with new technological advances (e.g. swimming) world records aren't changing much anymore. etc....

"Except for sports with new technological advances (e.g. swimming) world records aren't changing ..." False. Emerging markets have no records when created. It would be inaccurate static thinking to regard a category of current record to be ALL the records that will ever be. eg Global smartphone sales reach new record in Q2 2017. Markets are about what everyone wants, not what a single person notices. There will always be new records for new things.

Dai Qibao That's not even the point. CPUs are a somewhat old technology now, are not an emerging market and, as such, are seeing improvement slower and slower. Yes, new technologies will show up to set new records in new categories, but a specific way of doing things can only be made so good.
QuantumSeanyGlass "That's not even the point." What isn't the point about records not changing? "Yes, new technologies will show up to set new records" Ah, huh. That's a record.
Dai Qibao But I think we can safely say that new record appearing isn't records changing. At this point, I don't even know why you're arguing this, you only seem to disagree about the pedantics.

QuantumSeanyGlass "But I think we can safely say that new record appearing isn't records changing." *Oh. Neat." "world records aren't changing." False. "I don't even know why you're arguing this" Arguing what specifically? Perhaps read what I wrote and think about that instead?

Dai Qibao Your argument, and his, are exactly the same, but you have made it look like they're in competition. His argument is that existing industries and sports are stagnating and not improving while newer industries are what's really accelerating quickly. Your argument is that newer industries are what's really accelerating quickly. Your only objection is that he didn't include world records in new fields as part of world records despite the fact that he specifically exempted new fields from his argument about world records.

SPORTS MODIFIER " is NOT written to mean "except for new technology" as you assert.  QuantumSeanyGlass  "Your argument, and his, are exactly the same" False.  QuantumSeanyGlass  "His argument is that... while newer industries are what's really accelerating quickly." False. Agilemind didn't write that. You pretending to mind read this is impossible.  QuantumSeanyGlass "he specifically exempted new fields from his argument about world records." False. Read what he wrote, instead of pretending to mind read things not written.

Alright, let's break down what I understood from his comment. "Except for sports with new technological advances (e.g. swimming) world records aren't changing much anymore. etc...." So given that sports are mentioned here, we can assume he's referring to world records as commonly understood, referring to feats of physical strength or dexterity like measured at the Olympics. Sure, you can have world records for other things, but that's not what people are usually talking about when they refer to world records. As such, using sports with technological advances as a counterpoint to most of sports can be generalized to all areas pretty easily. People have been running, vaulting and all that stuff for a very long time, and most of the improvements that can be made have already been made, and as such, world records aren't changing very fast in these areas. This is meant to parallel improvements in CPUs. On the other hand, new swimsuit materials have allowed swimmers to experience less drag and swim faster; technology has allowed a significant leap in our capabilities from a source we'd never had access to before. This can parallel things like smartphones and social media that really aren't mature industries yet. I'd say that closely matches your argument.
Going from 50% efficiency to 90% (40% increase ) will always be easier than going from 90 to 95% (5%increase)

QuantumSeanyGlass "sports... new swimsuit materials have allowed swimmers... technology has allowed a significant leap in our capabilities from a source we'd never had access to before. This can parallel things like smartphones and social media that really aren't mature industries yet. I'd say that closely matches your argument." To be clear: I'm not relating a "static mind category" of improvement to the status quo (sports swim record) with "Emerging markets have no records when created", I'm directing attention one of countless  changes to the people valuations, which was a highly use valued CPU record, but has is now shifted toward highly valued use of smartphones "Global smartphone sales reach new record in Q2 2017" (market shift, emerging markets, subjective values). New records will ALWAYS be set because the peoples wants are infinite and their values are subjective. It would be STATIC thinking to regard a records as ALL THAT WILL EVER BE... thinking that is absent observed reality.  "technology has allowed a significant leap in our capabilities" Fundamentally peoples subjective wants "allowed" further capabilities. A new technology can and can't set records depending on what people value. A new technology can and cant make people capable depending on what people value.

tom keane  "Going from 50% efficiency to 90% (40% increase ) will always be easier than going from 90 to 95% (5%increase)" A person throws their "highest efficiency" desktop in the trash and uses a "lower efficiency" smart phone. Thus a geometric increase in their efficiency. As efficiency has always increased in this manner, it reasonable to assume the same geometric progression will continue. What use is a measure of efficiency for what a person has no value of? Resource use efficiency absent the information of peoples wants. Reciprocal exchange efficiency is dependent on aggregate wants of people.  Perhaps the aggregate information of wants peaking for Intel CPU's in 2011 then a shift toward other chips from nVidia and Samsung is a new efficiency record. My horse and buggy is very "efficient" for a horse and buggy... interested in it?

I think you're making some really interesting arguments here. I do think you're misreading the increase in smartphone sales; it's probably due to a larger portion of the world population being able to afford smartphones, probably in india and china, rather than users of other electronic devices switching over to smartphones. There's nothing that says you can't use both, and desktops are far better at many applications. I agree that the things which are valued highly will change, but records aren't usually about value, they're about some objective fact. Oh, sure, sales trends and records are based on our perception of value, and as such will vary wildly, but records like the land speed record or most efficient car or fastest human runner or most efficient CPU will have a tendency to grow more slowly over time. I think you're also right that these things would not be growing at all if nobody was willing to fund their development, if nobody valued their progress.

QuantumSeanyGlass "I do think you're misreading the increase in smartphone sales; it's probably due to" Increase of a new emerging markets for smartphones that didn't exist before. eg Quantity zero to 1 is a increase.  "it's probably due to..." Anyone can observe the increase market share of smartphones and decline in like use personal desktop CPU's  "There's nothing that says you can't use both" Anyone can observe people not using both by the market shift from away from person desktop to person smartphones.  "desktops are far better at many applications." Subjective valuation. Of significance to you, not others.  "records aren't usually about value" False. Someone subjectively must values it, otherwise it wouldn't happen.  "But records like the land speed record" Subjectively valued apparent by the company sponsored advertisements on the driver, vehicle and event grounds.  "most efficient car" Is a "subjective value" which some people value or don't. If NONE valued a efficient car, there it wouldn't exsist.  "fastest human runner" Subjectively valued apparent by Olympic games bid country. Olympic athlete Mark Philps endorsements of $20 million from Speedo, Powerbar, Omega, Hilton, and AT&T.  "or most efficient CPU" Is a "subjective value" which some people value or don't. if NONE valued a efficient CPU, it wouldn't exist. Regard the information of aggregate peoples self-invested wants.  The objective record only exists because someone is subjectively valuing it. Reasonably current Olympic sports are valued more than historic Olympic sports events, by the observation of viewership towards current Olympics events relative to lack of viewership in historical events.

Somebody could build a CPU that can do petaflops per second for only one watt, and it would be the most efficient CPU. It would break the record. Whether anyone cares or not is irrelevant to the breaking of records. Some guy could make the world's largest oatmeal raisin cookie and nobody would care, but the record is broken anyway. If people cared later, they could probably look back and find that this was indeed the world's largest raisin cookie. Sure, someone put in some work to break the record, which is an investment, but it could also be a secondary effect of completing some other task. In the case of olympic athletes, the people paying the athlete to run really don't care about the record being broken, they care about the public noticing and buying their equipment. The record being broken was not valued but happened anyway. Current olympic sports are valued more highly than historical olympic sports? I guess it's possible, but I think the relative viewership is probably due to the relative populations and ease of access. Historical events had to be attended in person, meaning you had to have a lot of money and free time to attend. The general public could have valued them the same and viewership still could've been lower. There was also far less people on earth. The global populations has more than doubled since 1950.  Desktop sales are dropping, true, but as the technology slows down, existing computers aren't made obsolete as often, and many people already have sufficiently new and powerful desktops. I doubt anyone's throwing away desktop computers to get a phone, and I strongly doubt anyone is making a decision between buying a desktop and a smartphone. They're used for different things. They're in different markets. Design work uses desktop computers and will probably continue to use desktop computers for the foreseeable future. You need the computing power to run simulations, compile code and encode videos. They also have their own games market which uses the power and easy input of desktops. The general public uses smartphones for their portability. They can be carried everywhere and allow communication across the world. Their ability as a computer is secondary to their value for accesing the internet and making calls. If for some reason desktops were primarily used for accessing the internet, they couldn't compete with phones, or if for some reason phones were primarily used for their computing power, they wouldn't be able to compete with desktops.  So if the reason smartphones are doing better isn't because they're outcompeting desktops, then it must be for other reasons, the mostly likely of these being they've entered new markets that desktops are still too expensive and not sufficiently broadly useful to enter. Like developing countries. I guess my point here is there's a lot more at play than just how much people value things. Demand isn't the only side of the equation.

"The objective record only exists because someone is subjectively valuing it."  Nonsense. The fastest land mammal would still exist regardless of whether some dude cares about it. The coldest place on earth would be the same temperature whether or not it is observed. The longest day of the year is still the longest regardless of whether any creature cares to measure it. The brightest star in the sky still shines whether or not anyone is looking at it.

"Current olympic sports are valued more highly than historical olympic sports?"  Thinking beyond the Olympics I find it hard to believe, at least one Roman Emperor was almost murdered by sports fans during a sport-related riot in ancient Rome.

chbrules Looking at other technology development, size, cost, speed and use, one can make fairly accurate conclusions.  At the time, people used inefficient and expensive vacuum pipes and it was a realistic vision of "a global market of about 4 computers".  Letting supply/demand take it forward would have meant going at a medieval pace. 50 years may be optimistic.  Some people thought the current computer would just be a thing of the past and go back to mechankcal ones. Internet as well.  The demand for the kind of computing they did back then was extremely small. There was even a profession called "computer" and it would in most cases be cheaper to hire a dude doing your computing needs.  Of course, ANY speculation on an alternative history IS speculation, but looking at the available evidence of the time, the only real variable that stands out for rapid development was the initial military applications. Just saying "we can't know anything" is pointless.  Point out some other concurrent variable to counter my argument. Now THAT is somethibg i don't think you can do.

I love all the soothsayers here. The market could never do this stuff! It could never find a use for this stuff! How could we ever survive without government throwing endless tax payer's money at stuff!?  +Darkstar22 - Deliciously ironic, no?

+chbrules the first 20-50 years of any major technological advance has to be subsidized by somebody because that is generally how long it takes to do all the research & work necessary to turn an idea in someone's head to a profit-generating product. The entity subsidizing the project might be the gov't (e.g. solar energy generation), it can also be super-rich individuals who have plenty of money to throw away on a dream (e.g. Larry Page, Jame Cameron), or just private passionate individuals who dedicate their lives savings to a personal project (e.g. Troy Hurtubise).

+Agilemind - Investments into the R&D of a technology isn't subsidization as a government does it. Those are two entire separate definitions of the word. Governments fund projects because it's by decree, and private interests invest in projects because they see it as potentially profitable or personally interesting. The list of spending on government projects over the years is in the many trillions. We see very little return. The private sector would be far more efficient at said tasks - and are.  It's utter nonsense that the private sector doesn't often invest in pure research and future technologies. Boeing photonics labs? IBM research? Bell Labs? Xerox Park? Hell, even Google, FB, and Twitter invest into theoretical computing research. Big tech businesses like pure research because there are often many practical applications and revolutionary ideas that come about that make the businesses even wealthier.
"Government merely hired the talent from the private sector" The function of government is to justify more spending, not providing anything.

"Letting supply/demand take it forward would have meant going at a medieval pace. 50 years may be optimistic." Analogous to: 100,000 people want resources to go toward innovating ALL others things by the calcuaiton of 100.000 self invested minds, but one person called "government" has a gun and forces those people not to innovate in EVERYTHING ELSE.  "Letting supply/demand take it forward would have meant going at a medieval pace. 50 years may be optimistic." And so what if allowing aggregate EVERYONE to innovate what they want slows the pace of what a few people in government want to justify taking tax for? I think you should pay for what you don't want, therefore I'm correct? Explain.  "Of course, ANY speculation on an alternative history IS speculation" False. It's not speculation to say resources where diverted from ALL other innovations by government authority in a system that lacks economic calculation.

Governments fund projects because it's by decree, and private interests invest in projects because they see it as potentially profitable or personally interesting.   Government decrees are based on what "the public" or "the dictator" has decided is potentially profitable or personally interesting, so how are these different?

The fundamental relationship is different. xspager I'm Russian, two of my grandparents were employed as programmers at around this time. It wasn't an uncommon job and a lot was developed differently because the US and USSR had very different standards. There is a lot that could have been talked about in this episode, like the BESM which was a computer developed in the USSR. In the 1970s its 6th edition was way ahead of any American computing technology. It also entered the European market and had as much, if not more, influence there than American tech.
If you make your own video about Russian computers, I'll watch it.  But, I may be as critical of your content as you've been of theirs.

My main complaint with your original comment is that it poorly considers the difficulties in editing a video like this. 11 minutes of video, and an audience probable to number in the hundred thousands. They're going to have to gloss over some material.   They make decisions about what content to gloss over during pre-production. That editing is difficult. Sony and the Japanese electronics industry also got a boost from the cargo ships carrying military supplies from Los Angeles to Vietnam.
